partial_orders.reason: Both edits perform an identical structural substitution pattern, replacing deprecated pandas chained indexing syntax (frame['column'][rows] = value) with the recommended .iloc approach (frame.iloc[rows, frame.columns.get_loc('column')] = value). This is a uniform refactoring pattern applied to the same type of syntactic construct (DataFrame assignment operations) across different test files. The edits are part of the same bulk modernization effort to eliminate chained indexing warnings, making them part of a single, contiguous refactoring sweep with identical before→after transformation patterns.

Both edits perform an identical structural substitution pattern, replacing deprecated pandas chained indexing syntax (frame['column'][rows] = value) with the recommended .iloc approach (frame.iloc[rows, frame.columns.get_loc('column')] = value). This is a uniform refactoring pattern applied to the same type of syntactic construct (DataFrame assignment operations) across different test files. The edits are part of the same bulk modernization effort to eliminate chained indexing warnings, making them part of a single, contiguous refactoring sweep with identical before→after transformation patterns.

Both edits are replacing deprecated pandas indexing patterns with modern, recommended approaches. Edit 0 changes `tail["A"][:10] = 0` to `tail.iloc[:10, tail.columns.get_loc("A")] = 0`, while Edit 1 changes `frame_copy["C"][:5] = np.nan` to `frame_copy.loc[: frame_copy.index[4], "C"] = np.nan`. These are identical structural transformations (chained indexing → .iloc/.loc) applied to the same type of syntactic construct (DataFrame column assignment with slice indexing). This represents a bulk refactoring pattern where the same before→after substitution is being applied uniformly across the codebase to modernize indexing practices.

Both edits perform identical structural substitutions within the same test method, changing from `.loc[index].values[:] = value` pattern to `.iloc[slice] = value` pattern. This represents a uniform refactoring pattern applied to the same type of syntactic construct (assignment statements) within the same function context. The edits are part of a single, contiguous refactoring task to update the test assertion methodology.

Both edits perform the same type of refactoring pattern - replacing deprecated pandas indexing syntax with the recommended .loc accessor. Edit 0 changes from frame_copy['C'][:5] to frame_copy.loc[:frame_copy.index[4], 'C'], and edit 1 changes from x.col2[x.index[-1]] to x.loc[x.index[-1], 'col2']. However, these are different symbols in different files and contexts - 'frame_copy' vs 'x', and 'C' vs 'col2'. While they follow the same refactoring pattern (chained indexing to .loc), they reference completely different dataframe objects and columns. This is a bulk refactoring pattern but not on the exact same symbols.
